2018|via=www.theguardian.com}} Dutton then resigned from the Ministry despite being offered by Turnbull to retain his position of [[Minister for Home Affairs (Australia)|Minister for Home Affairs]], and the media speculated that Dutton and his conservative backers in the party were likely to challenge for the leadership again in the near future.{{cite web|url=https://www.afr.com/news/peter-duttons-backers-vow-its-not-over-for-malcolm-turnbull-20180820-h148mw|title=Peter Dutton's backers vow it's not over for Malcolm Turnbull|work=Australian Financial Review|date=21 August 2018|first=Phil|last=Coorey}} Three days later, Dutton called for another leadership spill, and [[Malcolm Turnbull]] tendered his resignation to the Governor-General. Dutton was defeated by Treasurer and Acting Home Affairs Minister [[Scott Morrison]] by 45 votes to 40. Doubts surrounding Dutton's eligibility to be elected to parliament emerged on the grounds of [[Section 44 of the Constitution of Australia#(v) Pecuniary interest in an agreement with the Commonwealth|section 44(v) of the Australian Constitution]], as the [[family trust]] owned by Dutton operated a [[child care]] centre that received over $5.6 million in funding from the [[Government of Australia|Commonwealth Government]], in a situation similar to [[Re Day (No 2)|Bob Day's case]]. Although Dutton had received legal advice stating that he was not in breach of section 44(v), Labor had received contrary advice; at Turnbull's request, the [[Attorney-General for Australia|Attorney-General]] referred the matter to the [[Solicitor-General of Australia|Solicitor-General]].{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/government-refers-dutton-s-eligibility-to-solicitor-general-20180822-p4zyy6.html |title=Government refers Dutton's eligibility to Solicitor-General |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=22 August 2018 |last1=Loussikian |first1=Kylar |last2=McCauley |first2=Dana}} On 23 August, Labor attempted to move a motion to refer Dutton's eligibility as an MP to the [[High Court of Australia|High Court]], in a similar manner to referrals made during [[2017–18 Australian parliamentary eligibility crisis|the recent parliamentary citizenship crisis]]. The motion failed by 69 votes to 68.{{cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/labor-s-dutton-court-check-push-defeated|title= Labor's Dutton court check push defeated|date=23 August 2018|agency=[[Australian Associated Press]]|access-date=23 August 2018|work=[[SBS News]]}} On 24 August, the Solicitor-General advised that in terms of section 44(v) Dutton was "not incapable" of sitting as an MP, although he added that he had been provided with limited factual information and that, owing to differences of judicial opinion in earlier decisions of the High Court on section 44(v), Dutton's legal position could not be entirely clear without a referral to the High Court.{{cite news |title=Solicitor-General suggests Peter Dutton can stay in Parliament amid eligibility cloud |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-08-24/dutton-legal-advice-clears-path-for-pm-bid/10159702 |accessdate=26 August 2018 |work=ABC News |date=24 August 2018 |language=en-AU}}{{ cite web|url=https://auspublaw.org/2018/09/section-44-and-the-competing-arguments-for-disqualification-and-exoneration-of-peter-dutton|last=Twomey|first=Anne|title=Section 44 and the Competing Arguments for Disqualification and Exoneration of Peter Dutton|website=AUSPUBLAW|date=5 September 2018|accessdate=5 September 2018}} Dutton was reappointed to his former Home Affairs portfolio by [[Scott Morrison]] in the [[Morrison Ministry]], however the duties of Immigration and Border Protection were stripped from the role and were assigned to [[David Coleman (Australian politician)|David Sydney Morning Herald]]'' that Dutton "said privately it was inevitable that same-sex marriage would become law in Australia so it would be better for the Coalition, rather than Labor, to control the process". Dutton's actions publicly have been in opposition to same-sex advocates and "the forcefulness of Mr Dutton's attack on corporate chief executives last week - in which he told them to 'stick to their knitting' - has aroused suspicion among some colleagues who believed he was committed to achieving a breakthrough on [same-sex marriage]".{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/peter-dutton-working-behind-the-scenes-to-legislate-samesex-marriage-before-ceo-spray-20170320-gv2lcq.html|title=Peter Dutton working behind the scenes to legislate same-sex marriage before CEO spray|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=22 March 2017|accessdate=2 April 2017|author=Matthew Knott}} The following month ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that Dutton was asked by a lesbian for clarification on his position, and he "told her he had been clear that he was against same-sex marriage". In his political career, Dutton has voted "very strongly against same sex marriage".{{Cite web|url=http://www.openaustralia.org.au/mp/peter_dutton/dickson|title=Peter Dutton MP, Dickson (OpenAustralia.org)|website=www.openaustralia.org.au|access-date=2017-06-15}} However, he voted in favour of the ''[[Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Act 2017]]'', which legalised same-sex marriage; 65 percent of his constituency voted "Yes" in the [[Australian Marriage Law Postal Survey]].{{Cite Hansard|jurisdiction=Australia |title=HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES - Hansard|hansard=Record of Proceedings (Hansard)|url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/download/chamber/hansardr/716f5e71-dee3-40a3-9385-653e048de81b/toc_pdf/House%20of%20Representatives_2017_12_07_5783_Official.pdf;fileType=application%2Fpdf |house=[[Australian House of Representatives]] |date=7 December 2017|page=13143-13145}} In March 2017, 31 CEOs signed a letter to Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull calling for a free vote in the Australian Parliament on same-sex marriage. In response to this letter, on 16 March 2017, Dutton said that the CEOs "shouldn't shove their views down our throats" and that CEOs who were "doing the wrong thing" should "be publicly shamed".{{Cite web | url=http://www.minister.border.gov.au/peterdutton/Pages/int-with-Ray-Hadley,-Radio-2GB4BC.aspx | title=Interview with Ray Hadley, Radio 2GB-4BC | last=Dutton | first=Peter | date=16 March 2017 | website=The Hon Peter Dutton MP, Minister for Immigration and Border Protection | access-date=24 March 2017}} Dutton repeated his criticism at a speech to the LNP State Council in Queensland on 18 March.{{Cite web | url=http://www.minister.border.gov.au/peterdutton/Pages/Address-to-the-LNP-State-Council,-Cairns.aspx | title=Address to the LNP State Council, Cairns | last=Dutton | first=Peter | date=18 March 2017 | website=The Hon Peter Dutton MP, Minister for Immigration and Border Protection|access-date=24 March 2017}} Dutton’s comments were heavily criticised as an attempt to censor expressions of support for same-sex marriage, with some commenters also accusing him of hypocrisy given his support for changing [[Racial_Discrimination_Act_1975#Section_18C:_Prohibition_on_offense.2C_insult.2C_humiliation_or_intimidation_and_Exemptions_under_Section_18D|Section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act]].{{Cite web | url=https://theconversation.com/free-speech-it-depends-who-you-are-in-peter-duttons-view-74818 | title=Free speech? It depends who you are, in Peter Dutton’s view | last=Grattan | first=Michelle | date=19 March 2017 | website=The Conversation | access-date=24 March 2017}} Former New South Wales Premier [[Kristina Keneally]] said that according to Dutton, "Free speech is great and should be expanded, unless it’s an Australian corporate CEO speaking about same-sex marriage. Then they need to shut up.”{{Cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/mar/20/is-peter-dutton-setting-the-stage-for-his-coming-prime-ministership?CMP=soc_567 | title=Peter Dutton shines as a minister when his opponents can't be heard | last=Keneally | first=Kristina | date=20 March 2017 | website=The Guardian | access-date=24 March 2017}} Liberal MPs and ministers Julie Bishop and [[Simon Birmingham]] also expressed disagreement with Dutton’s comments.{{Cite web | url=http://www.news.com.au/national/politics/peter-dutton-slapped-down-over-comments-on-the-gay-marriage-debate/news-story/ca83f872ce7cd346aab26ffd920d6dd0 | title=Peter Dutton slapped down over comments on the gay marriage debate | date=19 March 2017|website=News.com.au|access-date=24 March 2017}} On 9 May 2017, a 67-year-old man pushed a pie into the face of Qantas CEO Alan Joyce while Joyce was speaking at a function in Perth. The next day, the assailant confirmed that the attack was to protest against Joyce's support for same-sex marriage.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-05-10/qantas-alan-joyce-pie-thrower-against-gay-marriage/8513596|title=Man launched pie at Qantas chief Alan Joyce 'to oppose gay marriage'|date=10 May 2017|website=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|access-date=10 May 2017}} Dutton had singled out Joyce in his criticism of pro-same-sex marriage CEOs,{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/politics/stick-to-your-knitting-dutton-tells-ceos-to-stay-out-of-gay-marriage/news-story/e3e2cf4d8da68a0ffab57c42d6a27fa0|title=‘Stick to your knitting’: Dutton tells CEO’s to stay out of gay marriage|date=19 March 2017|website=News.com.au|access-date=10 May 2017}} leading some LGBTI advocates to hold him partially responsible for the attack.{{Cite web|url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/national-news/alan-joyce-qantas-pie-anti-marriage-equality-protest/158123|title=Qantas CEO Alan Joyce Attacked With Pie Over Marriage Equality|last=Barber|first=Laurence|date=10 May 2017|website=Star Observer|access-date=10 May 2017}} Dutton condemned the attack on Twitter.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/PeterDutton_MP/status/861767699524763648|title=Peter Dutton|date= 9 May 2017|website=Twitter|access-date=10 May 2017}} ===Negative gearing=== Dutton, who owns six properties with his wife, including a shopping centre in [[Townsville]], opposes any changes to [[negative gearing]] which currently offers tax breaks to property investors, stating that changing it would harm the economy.{{cite news|last1=Cadzow|first1=Jane|title=Peter Dutton: 'I'm just not impacted by that hatred'|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/good-weekend/peter-dutton-im-just-not-impacted-by-that-hatred-20170516-gw5pt1.html|accessdate=28 May 2017|work=Brisbane Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=26 May 2017}} === White genocide conspiracy theory === Dutton has been accused of supporting and promoting the [[white genocide conspiracy theory]].{{cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-za/news/editorpicks/bongani-bingwa-white-genocide-is-a-lie/ar-BBKhwQ9 |title=Bongani Bingwa: White genocide is a lie |date=16 March 2018 |publisher=[[MSN News]]}}{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/1367287/donald-trump-wants-to-help-south-africas-white-farmers/ |title=Trump and the man trying to topple Australia’s government share an affinity for helping South Africa’s white farmers |date=23 August 2018 |publisher=''[[Quartz (publication)]]''}}{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/controversial-australian-minister-peter-dutton-the-next-prime-minister-or-the-great-divider-20180322 |title=Controversial Australian Minister Dutton the next prime minister, or the great divider? |date=22 March 2018 |publisher=[[News24]]}}{{cite news|title=The creeping spectre of "white genocide" 2018 |publisher=[[Aljazeera.com]]}} In 2018, he declared that [[Boers]] required refugee status in Australia because of "the horrific circumstances they face" in South Africa.{{cite farmers in South Africa - and why the right is obsessed with them |date=23 August 2018 |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''}} [[BBC News]] reported that the [[Suidlanders]] group's "message of white genocide" had "resonated" with Dutton, prompting him to offer fast-track visas to [[white South African]] farmers due to their being "persecuted", claiming they needed help from a "civilised" country.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-45336840 |title=South Africa: The groups playing on the fears of a 'white genocide’ |date=1 September 2018 |publisher=[[BBC]]}} ==Personal '''Polymorphous perversity''' is a [[psychoanalytic]] concept proposing the ability to gain [[sexual gratification]] outside [[social norm|socially normative]] sexual behaviors. [[Sigmund Freud]] used this term to describe the sexual disposition from infancy to about age five.
==Freud's theory==
Freud theorized that some are born with unfocused pleasure / [[libido|libidinal]] drives, deriving pleasure from any part of the body. The objects and modes of pleasurable satisfaction are multifarious, directed at every object that might provide pleasure. Polymorphous perverse sexuality continues from infancy through about age five, progressing through three distinct developmental stages: the [[oral stage]], [[anal stage]], and [[Genital stage|genital / phallic stage]]. Only in subsequent developmental stages do children learn to constrain drives towards pleasure-satisfaction to socially accepted norms, culminating in adult [[heterosexuality|heterosexual]] behavior focused on the genitals and reproduction or sublimations of the procreative drive.
Freud taught that during this stage of undifferentiated impulse for pleasure, [[incest]]uous and [[bisexuality|bisexual]] urges are normal. Lacking knowledge that certain modes of gratification are forbidden, the polymorphously perverse child seeks gratification wherever it occurs. In the earliest phase, the oral phase, the child forms a libidinal bond with the mother via the inherent pleasure gained from [[breastfeeding|suckling at the breast]].
For Freud, "perversion" is a non-judgmental term. He used it to designate behavior outside the socially acceptable norms of his era.
==See also== * [[Oedipus complex]] * [[Sexual fetishism]] * [[Paraphilia]]

'''Primary goods''' are presented in the important book ''[[A Theory of Justice]]'' (1971) written by the American philosopher [[John Rawls]]. In the first edition of the ''Theory of Justice'', these goods are supposed to be desirable for every human being, just as they are also useful for them. Thus, primary goods are the common base for the unanimous selection of the justice principle in the [[original position]].
Primary goods are subdivided in two categories: * ''Natural primary goods'': this category includes intelligence, imagination, health, speed etc. * ''Social primary goods'': this category includes rights (civil rights and political rights), liberties, income and wealth, the social bases of self-respect, etc.
In the second edition of the ''Theory of Justice'', primary goods are stated to be those that the citizens need as free people and as members of the society.
==See also== * [[John Rawls]] * [[Welfarism]] * [[Utilitarianism]]
==References== <references /> * Rawls J., ''A Theory of Justice'', Belknap, United States, 1971. * [[Amartya Sen|Sen A.]], Equality of What?, The Tanner Lecture on Human Values, Stanford University, May 1979.

'''Priming''' is a technique whereby exposure to one [[stimulus (psychology)|stimulus]] influences a response to a subsequent stimulus, without conscious guidance or intention.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weingarten et al.|first=|date=2016|title=From primed concepts to action: A meta-analysis of the behavioral effects of incidentally presented words.|url=|journal=Psychological Bulletin|volume=142|pages=472–497|via=|doi=10.1037/bul0000030}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Studying the Mind in the Middle: A Practical Guide to Priming and Automaticity Research. In Handbook of Research Methods in Social Psychology|last=Bargh, J. A., & Chartrand, T. L.|first=|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2000|isbn=|editor-last=Reis, H., & Judd, C.|location=New York, NY|pages=1–39}}</ref> For example, the word <tt>NURSE</tt> is recognized more quickly following the word <tt>DOCTOR</tt> than following the word <tt>BREAD</tt>. Priming can be [[perceptual]], [[semantic]], or [[wikt:conceptual|conceptual]]. Research, however, has yet to firmly establish the duration (a day? a week?) of priming effects,<ref name="tulv">{{cite journal|last1=Tulving|first1=Endel|last2=Schacter|first2=Daniel L.|last3=Stark|first3=Heather A.|year=1982|title=Priming Effects in Word Fragment Completion are independent of Recognition Memory|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|volume=8|issue=4}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bargh, J. A., Gollwitzer, P. M., Lee-Chai, A., Barndollar, K., & Trötschel, R.|first=|date=2001|title=The automated will: nonconscious activation and pursuit of behavioral goals.|url=|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=|pages=1014–1027|via=|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.81.6.1014}}</ref> yet their onset can be almost instantaneous.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ben-Haim|first=Moshe Shay|last2=Chajut|first2=Eran|last3=Hassin|first3=Ran R.|last4=Algom|first4=Daniel|date=2015|title=Speeded naming or naming speed? The automatic effect of object speed on performance.|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/a0038569|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: General|language=en|volume=144|issue=2|pages=326–338|doi=10.1037/a0038569|issn=1939-2222}}</ref>
Priming works best when the two stimuli are in the same [[modality (semiotics)|modality]]. For example, visual priming works best with visual cues and verbal priming works best with verbal cues. But priming also occurs between modalities,<ref>Several researchers, for example, have used cross-modal priming to investigate [[Syntax|syntactic]] deficits in individuals with damage to [[Broca's area]] of the brain. See the following: *{{cite journal | last1 = Zurif | first1 = E.B. | last2 = Swinney | first2 = D. | last3 = Prather | first3 = P. | last4 = Solomon | first4 = J. | last5 = Bushell | first5 = C. |name-list-format=vanc| year = 1993 | title = An on-line analysis of syntactic processing in Broca's and Wernicke's aphasia | url = | journal = Brain and Language | volume = 45 | issue = 3| pages = 448–464 | doi = 10.1006/brln.1993.1054 | pmid = 8269334 }} *Swinney, D., E. Zurif, P. Prather, and T. Love (1993). "The neurological distribution of processing operations underlying language comprehension." Manuscript, Department of Psychology, University of California, San Diego. *For an overview, see also Zurif, E.B. (1995), "Brain Regions of Relevance to Syntactic Processing." in ''Knowledge of Meaning: An Introduction to Semantic Theory'', eds. Richard Larson and Gabriel Segal. MIT Press.</ref> or between [[Semantics|semantically]] related words such as "doctor" and "nurse".<ref name="MS71">{{cite journal|last1=Meyer|first1=D.E.|last2=Schvaneveldt|first2=R.W.|year=1971|title=Facilitation in recognizing pairs of words: Evidence of a dependence between retrieval operations|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology|volume=90|issue=2|pages=227–234|doi=10.1037/h0031564}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.3758/BF03211539 | title=Lexical integration: Sequential effects of syntactic and semantic information | last1=Friederici | first1=Angela D. | first2=Karsten | last2=Steinhauer | first3=Stefan | last3=Frisch | year=1999 | journal=Memory & Cognition | volume = 27 | issue=3 | pages=438–453 | quote=''Semantic priming'' refers to the finding that word recognition is typically faster when the target word (e.g., ''doctor'') is preceded by a semantically related prime word (e.g., ''nurse'').}}</ref>
==Types== ===Positive and negative priming=== The terms ''positive'' and ''negative'' priming refer to when priming affects the speed of processing. A positive prime speeds up processing, while a negative prime lowers the speed to slower than un-primed levels.<ref name=neg>{{cite journal | doi=10.1027/0044-3409.215.1.35 |title=Negative Priming as a Memory Phenomenon: A Review of 20 Years of Negative Priming Research | last1=Mayr | first1=Susanne | first2=Axel | last2=Buchner | year=2007 | journal=Journal of Psychology | pages=35–51 | volume=215 | issue=1}}</ref> Positive priming is caused by simply experiencing the stimulus,<ref name=reis>Reisberg, Daniel: ''Cognition: Exploring the Science of the Mind'' (2007), page 255, 517.</ref> while negative priming is caused by experiencing the stimulus, and then ignoring it.<ref name=neg/><ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1037/0278-7393.17.6.1136 | first1=Ewald| last1=Neumann| first2=Brett G.| last2=DeSchepper| title=Costs and Benefits of Target Activation and Distractor Inhibition in Selective Attention | journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition | volume=17 | issue=6| year=1991 | pages=1136–1145}}</ref> Positive priming effects happen even if the prime is not consciously seen.<ref name=reis/> The effects of positive and negative priming are visible in [[Event-related potential|event-related potential (ERP)]] readings.<ref>{{cite journal | first1=Shlomo| last1=Bentin| first2=Gregory| last2=McCarthy| first3=Charles C.| last3=Wood | title=Event Related Potentials, Lexical Decision and Semantic Priming | journal=Electroencephalography and Clinical Neurophysiology | volume=60 | year=1985 | doi=10.1016/0013-4694(85)90008-2 | pages=343–355}}</ref>
Positive priming is thought to be caused by spreading activation.<ref name=reis/> This means that the first stimulus activates parts of a particular representation or [[association (psychology)|association]] in [[memory]] just before carrying out an action or task. The representation is already partially activated when the second stimulus is encountered, so less additional activation is needed for one to become consciously aware of it.
Negative priming is more difficult to explain. Many models have been hypothesized, but currently the most widely accepted are the distractor inhibition and episodic retrieval models.<ref name=neg/> In the distractor inhibition model, the activation of ignored stimuli is inhibited by the brain.<ref name=neg/> The episodic retrieval model hypothesizes that ignored items are flagged 'do-not-respond' by the brain. Later, when the brain acts to retrieve this information, the tag causes a conflict. The time taken to resolve this conflict causes negative priming.<ref name=neg/> Although both models are still valid, recent scientific research has led scientists to lean away from the distractor inhibitor model.<ref name=neg />
===Perceptual and conceptual priming=== The difference between ''perceptual'' and ''conceptual'' primes is whether items with a similar ''form'' or items with a similar ''meaning'' are primed, respectively.
Perceptual priming is based on the form of the stimulus and is enhanced by the match between the early and later stimuli. Perceptual priming is sensitive to the modality and exact format of the stimulus. An example of perceptual priming is the identification of an incomplete word in a [[Indirect tests of memory#Word Stem Completion .28WSC.29 Task|word-stem completion test]]. The presentation of the visual prime does not have to be perfectly consistent with later testing presentations in order to work. Studies have shown that, for example, the absolute size of the stimuli can vary and still provide significant evidence of priming.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Size Invariance in Visual Object Priming | last1=Biederman| first1=Irving | first2=Eric E. | last2=Cooper | year=1992| journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance| volume=18 | issue=1| doi = 10.1037/0096-1523.18.1.121 | pages=121–133}}</ref>
Conceptual priming is based on the meaning of a stimulus and is enhanced by semantic tasks. For example, ''table'', will show priming effects on ''chair'', because ''table'' and ''chair'' belong to the same category.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://svalz.stanford.edu/docs/paper14.pdf | title=Dissociation between two forms of conceptual priming in Alzheimer's disease | last1=Vaidya | first1=Chandan L. | first2=Laura A. | last2=Monti | first3=John D.E. | last3=Gabrieli | first4=Jared R. | last4=Tinklenburg | first5=Jerome A. | last5=Yesevage | year=1999 | journal=Neuropsychology | volume=13 | issue=4 | pmid=10527059 | pages=516–24 | doi=10.1037/0894-4105.13.4.516 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719200220/http://svalz.stanford.edu/docs/paper14.pdf | archivedate=July 19, 2011 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Repetition=== ''[[Repetition priming]]'', also called ''direct priming'', is a form of positive priming. When a stimulus is experienced, it is also primed. This means that later experiences of the stimulus will be processed more quickly by the brain.<ref name=forster>{{cite journal | title=Repetition Priming and Frequency Attenuation | last1=Forster | first1=Kenneth I. | first2=Chris | last2=Davis | year=1984| journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition| volume=10 | issue=4}}</ref> This effect has been found on words in the [[Indirect tests of memory#Lexical Decision Task .28LDT.29|lexical decision task]].
===Semantic=== [[File:Priming Web Diagram.svg|thumb|300px|This image shows a priming web built from different types of priming. The lines in this web indicate associations that an individual might have. If two words are more closely linked in the web, then they are more likely to be more quickly recognized when primed with a nearby word. The dotted lines indicate morpheme primes, or primes from words that sound similar to each other, while the straight lines indicate semantic primes or words that have meanings or associations that relate to each other.]]
In ''semantic priming'', the prime and the target are from the same semantic category and share features.<ref>Ludovic Ferrand and Boris New: Semantic and associative priming in the mental lexicon, found on: boris.new.googlepages.com/Semantic-final-2003.pdf</ref> For example, the word ''dog'' is a semantic prime for ''wolf'', because the two are similar animals. Semantic priming is theorized to work because of [[spreading activation]] within associative networks.<ref name=reis /> When a person thinks of one item in a category, similar items are stimulated by the brain. Even if they are not words, [[morpheme]]s can prime for complete words that include them.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Morphology and Meaning in the English Mental Lexicon | last1=Marslen-Wilson | first1=William | first2=Lorraine Komisarjevsky | last2=Tyler | first3=Rachelle | last3=Waksler | year=1994 | journal=Psychological Review | volume=101 | issue=1 | doi = 10.1037/0033-295x.101.1.3 | pages=3–33}}</ref> An example of this would be that the morpheme 'psych' can prime for the word 'psychology'.
In support with further detail, when an individual processes a word sometimes that word can be affected when the prior word is linked semantically. Previous studies have been conducted, focusing on priming effects having a rapid rise time and a hasty decay time. For example, an experiment by Donald Frost researched the decay time of semantic facilitation in lists and sentences. Three experiments were conducted and it was found that semantic relationships within words differs when words occur in sentences rather than lists. Thus, supporting the ongoing discourse model.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0010028582900202|title=A discourse on semantic priming|last=Foss|first=Donald|date=April 23, 1982|access-date=|doi=10.1016/0010-0285(82)90020-2|volume=14|journal=Cognitive Psychology|pages=590–607}}</ref>
===Associative priming=== In ''associative priming'', the target is a word that has a high probability of appearing with the prime, and is "associated" with it but not necessarily related in semantic features. ''dog'' is an associative prime for ''cat'', since the words are closely associated and frequently appear together (in phrases like "raining cats and dogs").<ref>{{cite journal | first1=Junko | last1=Matsukawa | first2=Joan Gay | last2=Snodgrass | first3=Glen M. | last3=Doniger | title=Conceptual versus perceptual priming in incomplete picture identification | journal=Journal of Psycholinguistic Research | volume=34 | issue=6 | year=2005}}</ref> A similar effect is known as ''context priming''. Context priming works by using a context to speed up processing for stimuli that are likely to occur in that context. A useful application of this effect is reading written text.<ref name=stano>{{cite journal | first1=Keith E. | last1=Stanovich | first2=Richard F. | last2=West | title=On Priming by a Sentence Context | journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology | volume=112 | issue=1 | year=1983 | doi = 10.1037/0096-3445.112.1.1 | pmid=6221061 | pages=1–36}}</ref> The grammar and vocabulary of the sentence provide contextual clues for words that will occur later in the sentence. These later words are processed more quickly than if they had been read alone, and the effect is greater for more difficult or uncommon words.<ref name=stano />
===Response priming=== In the psychology of visual perception and motor control, the term ''[[response priming]]'' denotes a special form of visuomotor priming effect. The distinctive feature of response priming is that prime and target are presented in quick succession (typically, less than 100 milliseconds apart) and are coupled to identical or alternative motor responses.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Klotz | first1 = W. | last2 = Wolff | first2 = P. | year = 1995 | title = The effect of a masked stimulus on the response to the masking stimulus | url = | journal = Psychological Research | volume = 58 | issue = 2| pages = 92–101 | doi=10.1007/bf00571098| pmid = 7480512 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Klotz | first1 = W. | last2 = Neumann | first2 = O. | year = 1999 | title = Motor activation without conscious discrimination in metacontrast masking | url = | journal = Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance | volume = 25 | issue = 4| pages = 976–992 | doi=10.1037/0096-1523.25.4.976}}</ref> When a speeded motor response is performed to classify the target stimulus, a prime immediately preceding the target can thus induce response conflicts when assigned to a different response as the target. These response conflicts have observable effects on motor behavior, leading to priming effects, e.g., in response times and error rates. A special property of response priming is its independence from visual awareness of the prime: For example, response priming effects can increase under conditions where visual awareness of the prime is decreasing.<ref>Vorberg, D., Mattler, U., Heinecke, A., Schmidt, T., & Schwarzbach, J. ''Different time courses for visual perception and action priming.'' In: ''Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA'', 100, 2003, p. 6275-6280.</ref><ref>Schmidt, T., & Vorberg, D. ''Criteria for unconscious cognition: Three types of dissociation.'' In: ''Perception & Psychophysics'', 68, 2006, p. 489-504.</ref>
===Masked priming=== The masked priming paradigm has been widely used in the last two decades in order to investigate both [[orthography|orthographic]] and [[phonological]] activations during [[visual word recognition]]. The term "masked" refers to the fact that the prime word or pseudoword is masked by symbols such as ###### that can be presented in a forward manner (before the prime) or a backward manner (after the prime). These masks enable to diminish the visibility of the prime. The prime is usually presented less than 80 ms (but typically between 40-60 ms) in this paradigm. In all, the short SOA (Stimuli Onset Asynchrony, i.e. the time delay between the onset of the mask and the prime) associated with the masking make the masked priming paradigm a good tool to investigate automatic and irrepressive activations during visual word recognition.<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1037/0278-7393.10.4.680 |title=Repetition priming and frequency attenuation in lexical decision | last1=Forster | first1=K.I. | last2=Davis | first2=C. | year=1984 | journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition | pages=680–698 | volume=10 | issue=4}}</ref> Forster has argued that masked priming is a purer form of priming, as any conscious appreciation of the relationship between the prime and the target is effectively eliminated, and thus removes the subject's ability to use the prime strategically to make decisions. Results from numerous experiments show that certain forms of priming occur that are very difficult to occur with visible primes. One such example is form-priming, where the prime is similar to, but not identical to the target (e.g., ''nature''-''mature'').<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1016/0749-596X(91)90008-8 |title=The density constraint on form-priming in the naming task: Interference effects from a masked prime | last1=Forster | first1=K.I. | last2=Davis | first2=C. | year=1984 | journal=Journal of Memory and Language | pages=1–25 | volume=30 | issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1080/14640748708401785 | title=Masked priming with graphemically related forms: Repetition or partial activation? | last1 = Forster | first1=K.I. | last2=Davis | first2=C. | last3=Schoknecht | first3=C. | last4=Carter | first4=R. | year=1987 | journal=The Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology A: Human Experimental Psychology | pages=211–251 | volume=39A | issue=2}}</ref>
===Kindness priming=== [[Kindness priming (psychology)|Kindness priming]] is a specific form of priming that occurs when a subject experiences an act of kindness and subsequently experiences a lower threshold of activation when subsequently encountering positive stimuli. A unique feature of kindness priming is that it causes a temporarily increased resistance to negative stimuli in addition to the increased activation of positive associative networks.<ref name=carlson>Carlson, Charlin, Norman, http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/psp/55/2/211/, Positive mood and helping behavior: A test of six hypotheses, 1989</ref>
==Measuring the effects of priming== Priming effects can be found with many of the [[Indirect tests of memory|tests of implicit memory]]. Tests such as the [[Indirect tests of memory#Word Stem Completion .28WSC.29 Task|word-stem completion task]], and the [[Indirect tests of memory#Word Fragment Completion .28WFC.29|word fragment completion task]] measure [[#Perceptual_and_conceptual_priming|perceptual priming]]. In the word-stem completion task, participants are given a list of study words, and then asked to complete word "stems" consisting of 3 letters with the first word that comes to mind. A priming effect is observed when participants complete stems with words on the study list more often than with novel words. The word fragment completion task is similar, but instead of being given the stem of a word, participants are given a word with some letters missing. The [[Indirect tests of memory#Lexical Decision Task .28LDT.29|lexical decision task]] can be used to demonstrate [[#Types Of Priming|conceptual priming]].<ref name=MS71 /><ref name="SM73">{{Citation|title=Attention and performance IV|year=1973|last1=Schvaneveldt|last2=Meyer|first1=R.W.|first2=D.E.|pages=395–409|chapter=Retrieval and comparison processes in semantic memory|place=New York|publisher=Academic Press|editor-last=Kornblum|editor-first=S.}}</ref> In this task, participants are asked to determine if a given string is a word or a nonword. Priming is demonstrated when participants are quicker to respond to words that have been primed with semantically-related words, e.g., faster to confirm "nurse" as a word when it is preceded by "doctor" than when it is preceded by "butter". Other evidence has been found through brain imaging and studies from brain injured patients. Another example of priming in healthcare research was studying if safety behaviors of nurses could be primed by structuring [[Change-of-shift report|change of shift report]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Groves|first=Patricia S.|last2=Bunch|first2=Jacinda L.|last3=Cram|first3=Ellen|last4=Farag|first4=Amany|last5=Manges|first5=Kirstin|last6=Perkhounkova|first6=Yelena|last7=Scott-Cawiezell|first7=Jill|date=October 19, 2016|title=Priming Patient Safety Through Nursing Handoff Communication: A Simulation Pilot Study|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0193945916673358|journal=Western Journal of Nursing Research|volume=39|issue=11|language=en|pages=0193945916673358|doi=10.1177/0193945916673358|issn=0193-9459}}</ref> A pilot [[simulation]] study found that there is early evidence to show that safety behaviors can be primed by including safety language into report.<ref name=":0" />
==Effects of brain injuries== ===Amnesia=== [[Amnesia|Amnesic]] patients are described as those who have suffered damage to their [[Temporal lobe|medial temporal lobe]], resulting in the impairment of explicit recollection of everyday facts and events. Priming studies on amnesic patients have varying results, depending on both the type of priming test done, as well as the phrasing of the instructions.
Amnesic patients do as well on [[#Types Of Priming|''perceptual priming'']] tasks as healthy patients,<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1016/0028-3932(85)90063-6 | last1=Cermak | first1=L.S. | last4=Wolbarst |first4=L.R. | last2=Talbot | first2=N. | last3=Chandler | first3=K. | title=The perceptual priming phenomenon in amnesia | journal=Neuropsychologia | volume=23 | pages=615–622 | year=1985 | pmid=4058707 | issue=5}}</ref> however they show some difficulties completing [[#Types Of Priming|''conceptual priming'']] tasks, depending on the specific test. For example, they perform normally on category instance production tasks, but show impaired priming on any task that involves answering general knowledge questions.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Shimamura | first1=A.P.| last2=Squire | first2=L.R. | title=Paired-associate learning and priming effects in amnesia: a neuropsychological approach | year=1984 | journal=J. Exp. Psychol. | volume=113 | pages=556–570}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | first1=T.A. | last1=Blaxton | year=1992 | title=Dissociations among memory measures in memory-impaired subjects: evidence for a processing account of memory | journal=Mem. Cogn. | volume=15 | pages=549–562}}</ref>
Phrasing of the instructions associated with the test has had a dramatic impact on an amnesic's ability to complete the task successfully. When performing a [[Indirect tests of memory#Word Stem Completion .28WSC.29 Task|word-stem completion]] test, patients were able to successfully complete the task when asked to complete the stem using the first word that came to mind, but when explicitly asked to recall a word to complete the stem that was on the study list, patients performed at below-average levels.<ref>{{cite journal | first1=P. | last1=Graf | first2=L.R. | last2=Squire | first3=G. | last3=Mandler | year=1984 | title=The information that amnesic patients do not forget | journal=J. Exp. Psychol. | volume=10 | pages=164–178 | doi=10.1037/0278-7393.10.1.164}}</ref>
Overall, studies from amnesic patients indicate that priming is controlled by a brain system separate from the medial temporal system that supports [[explicit memory]].
===Aphasia=== Perhaps the first use of semantic priming in neurological patients was with stroke patients with [[aphasia]]. In one study, patients with Wernicke's aphasia who were unable to make semantic judgments showed evidence of semantic priming, while patient with Broca's aphasia who were able to make semantic judgments showed less consistent priming than Wernicke's aphasics or normal controls (Milberg and Blumstein 1981). This dissociation was extended to other linguistic categories such phonology and syntactic processing by Blumstein, Milberg and their colleagues.{{citation needed|date=February 2011}}
===Dementia=== Patients with [[Alzheimers|Alzheimer's disease (AD)]], the most common form of dementia, have been studied extensively as far as priming goes. Results are conflicting in some cases, but overall, AD patients show ''decreased'' priming effects on [[Indirect tests of memory#Word Stem Completion .28WSC.29 Task|word-stem completion]] and [[Free association (psychology)|free association]] tasks, while retaining normal performance on [[Indirect tests of memory#Lexical Decision Task .28LDT.29|lexical decision tasks]].<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1007/BF01108841 | last1=Carlesimo | first1=G.A. | last2=Oscarberman | first2=M. | year=1992 | title=Memory deficits in Alzheimer's patients: a comprehensive review | journal=Neuropsychology Review | volume=3 | issue=2 | pages=119–169 | pmid=1300219}}</ref> These results suggest that AD patients are impaired in any sort of priming task that requires semantic processing of the stimuli, while priming tasks that require visuoperceptual interpretation of stimuli are unaffected by Alzheimers.
===Focal cortical lesions=== Patient J.P., who suffered a stroke in the left medial/temporal gyrus, resulting in [[auditory verbal agnosia]] – the inability to comprehend spoken words, but maintaining the ability to read and write, and with no effects to hearing ability. J.P. showed normal [[#Types Of Priming|perceptual priming]], but his conceptual priming ability for spoken words was, expectedly, impaired.<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1037/0894-4105.7.2.107 | first1=D.L. | last1=Schacter | first2=S.M. | last2=McGlynn | first3=W.P. | last3=Milberg | first4=B.A. | last4=Church | year=1993 | title=Spared priming despite impaired comprehension: implicit memory in a case of word meaning deafness | journal=Neuropsychology | volume=7 | pages=107–118 | issue=2}}</ref> Another patient, N.G., who suffered from '''prosopanomia''' (the inability to retrieve proper names) following damage to his left temporal lobe, was unable to spontaneously provide names of persons or cities, but was able to successfully complete a word-fragment completion exercise following priming with these names. This demonstrated intact perceptual priming abilities.<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1037/0894-4105.11.2.232 | first1=A. | last1=Geva | first2=M. | last2=Moscovitch | first3=L. | last3=Leach | year=1997 | title=Perceptual priming of proper names in young and older normal adults and a patient with prosopanomia | journal=Neuropsychology | volume=11 | pages=232–242 | pmid=9110330 | issue=2}}</ref>
==Cognitive neuroscience== ===Perceptual priming=== [[File:Brodmann areas 17 18 19.png|thumb|The [[extrastriate cortex]] (shown in orange and red) is believed to be involved in perceptual priming]] Priming while improving performance decreases neural processing in the [[cerebral cortex]] of sensory stimuli with stimulus repetition. This has been found in single-cell recordings<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Li | first1 = L | last2 = Miller | first2 = EK | last3 = Desimone | first3 = R. |name-list-format=vanc| year = 1993 | title = The representation of stimulus familiarity in anterior inferior temporal cortex | url = | journal = J Neurophysiol | volume = 69 | issue = 6| pages = 1918–29 | pmid = 8350131 }}</ref> and in [[electroencephalography]] (EEG) upon [[gamma wave]]s,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11919002 | year = 2002 | last1 = Gruber | first1 = T | last2 = Müller | first2 = MM | title = Effects of picture repetition on induced gamma band responses, evoked potentials, and phase synchrony in the human EEG | volume = 13 | issue = 3 | pages = 377–92 | journal = Brain Research. Cognitive Brain Research | doi=10.1016/S0926-6410(01)00130-6}}</ref> with [[Positron Emission Tomography|PET]]<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1073/pnas.89.5.1837 | first1=L.R. | last1=Squire | first2=J.G. | last2=Ojemann | last3=Miezin | first3=F.M. | last4=Petersen | first4=S.E. | last5=Videen | first5=T.O. | last6=Raichle | first6=M.E. | year=1992 | title=Activation of the hippocampus in normal humans: a functional anatomical study of memory | journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA | volume=89 | pages=1837–1841 | pmid=1542680 | issue=5 | pmc=48548 | bibcode=1992PNAS...89.1837S }}</ref> and [[functional MRI]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 16056222 | year = 2005 | last1 = Wig | first1 = GS | last2 = Grafton | first2 = ST | last3 = Demos | first3 = KE | last4 = Kelley | first4 = WM | title = Reductions in neural activity underlie behavioral components of repetition priming | volume = 8 | issue = 9 | pages = 1228–33 | doi = 10.1038/nn1515 | journal = Nature Neuroscience }}</ref> This reduction is due to representational sharpening in the early sensory areas which reduces the number of neurons representing the stimulus. This leads to a more selective activation of neurons representing objects in higher cognitive areas.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Moldakarimov | first1 = S | last2 = Bazhenov | first2 = M | last3 = Sejnowski | first3 = TJ. |name-list-format=vanc| year = 2010 | title = Perceptual priming leads to reduction of gamma frequency oscillations | url = | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A | volume = 107 | issue = 12| pages = 5640–5645 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0907525107 | pmid = 20212165 | pmc = 2851786 | bibcode = 2010PNAS..107.5640M }}</ref>
===Conceptual priming=== Conceptual priming has been linked to reduced blood flow in the left [[prefrontal cortex]].<ref>{{cite journal | first1=J.B. | last1=Demb | first2=J.E. | last2=Desmond | first3=J.D.E. | last3=Gabrieli | title=Semantic encoding and retrieval in the left inferior prefrontal cortex: a functional MRI study of task difficulty and process specificity | year=1995 | journal=J. Neurosci. | volume=15 | pages=5870–5878 | pmid=7666172 | last4=Vaidya | first4=CJ | last5=Glover | first5=GH | last6=Gabrieli | first6=JD | issue=9}}</ref> The left prefrontal cortex is believed to be involved in the semantic processing of words, among other tasks.<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1073/pnas.95.3.906 | first1=J.D.E. | last1=Gabrieli | first2=R.A. | last2=Poldrack | first3=J.E. | last3=Desmond | year=1998 | title=The role of left prefrontal cortex in language and memory | journal=PNAS | volume=95 | pages=906–913 | pmid=9448258 | issue=3 | pmc=33815| bibcode=1998PNAS...95..906G }}</ref>
The view that perceptual priming is controlled by the extrastriate cortex while conceptual priming is controlled by the left prefrontal cortex is undoubtedly an oversimplified view of the process, and current work is focused on elucidating the brain regions involved in priming in more detail.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.casra.ch/teaching/2002/cns/doc/Dehaene_et_al_1998.pdf | pmid = 9783584 | year = 1998 | last1 = Dehaene | first1 = S | last2 = Naccache | first2 = L | last3 = Le Clec'h | first3 = G | last4 = Koechlin | first4 = E | last5 = Mueller | first5 = M | last6 = Dehaene-Lambertz | first6 = G | last7 = Van De Moortele | first7 = PF | last8 = Le Bihan | first8 = D | title = Imaging unconscious semantic priming | volume = 395 | issue = 6702 | pages = 597–600 | doi = 10.1038/26967 | journal = Nature | bibcode = 1998Natur.395..597D | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110706222851/http://www.casra.ch/teaching/2002/cns/doc/Dehaene_et_al_1998.pdf | archivedate = July 6, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
==In daily life== Priming is thought to play a large part in the systems of stereotyping. <ref name=auto>{{cite journal | first1=John A. | last1=Bargh | first2=Mark | last2=Chen | last3=Burrows | first3=Laura| year=1996 | title=Automaticity of Social Behavior: Direct Effects of Trait Construct and Stereotype Activation on Action | journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology| volume=71 | issue=2 | pmid=8765481 | pages=230–44 | doi=10.1037/0022-3514.71.2.230}}</ref> This is because attention to a response increases the frequency of that response, even if the attended response is undesired. <ref name=auto /><ref>(see [[Ironic process theory]] for a more in-depth discussion of this phenomenon)</ref> The attention given to these response or behaviours primes them for later activation.<ref name=auto /> Another way to explain this process is [[automaticity]]. If trait descriptions, for instance "stupid" or "friendly", have been frequently or recently used, these descriptions can be automatically used to interpret someone's behavior. An individual is unaware of this, and this may lead to behavior that may not agree with their personal beliefs.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Bargh | first1=J.A. | last2=Williams | first2=E.L. | title=The Automaticity of Social Life| year=2006 | journal= Current Directions in Psychological Science | volume=15| issue= 1 | pages=1–4 | doi=10.1111/j.0963-7214.2006.00395.x| pmid=18568084 | pmc=2435044}}</ref>
This can occur even if the subject is not conscious of the priming stimulus.<ref name=auto /> An example of this was done by [[John Bargh|Bargh]] et al. in 1996. Subjects were implicitly primed with words related to the stereotype of elderly people (example: Florida, forgetful, wrinkle). While the words did not explicitly mention speed or slowness, those who were primed with these words walked more slowly upon exiting the testing booth than those who were primed with neutral stimuli.<ref name=auto /> Similar effects were found with rude and polite stimuli: those primed with rude words were more likely to interrupt an investigator than those primed with neutral words, and those primed with polite words were the least likely to interrupt.<ref name=auto /> A [[Yale university|Yale]] study showed that something as simple as holding a hot or cold beverage before an interview could result in pleasant or negative opinion of the interviewer.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Williams | first1=Lawrence | last2=Bargh | first2=John | title=Experiencing physical warmth promotes psychological warmth| year=2008 | journal= Science | volume=322| issue= 5901| pages=606–607 | doi=10.1126/science.1162548| bibcode=2008Sci...322..606W }}</ref> However, there has been a serious lack of replication (see below).
These findings have been extended to therapeutic interventions. For example, Cox et al. (2012) suggest that presented with a depressed patient who "self-stereotypes herself as incompetent, a therapist can find ways to prime her with specific situations in which she had been competent in the past... Making memories of her competence more salient should reduce her self-stereotype of incompetence."<ref name="Cox et al. (2012)">{{cite journal |last1= Cox |first1= William T. L. |last2= Abramson |first2= Lyn Y. |last3= Devine |first3= Patricia G. |last4= Hollon |first4= Steven D. |year= 2012 |title= Stereotypes, Prejudice, and Depression: The Integrated Perspective |journal= [[Perspectives on Psychological Science]] |volume= 7 |issue= 5 |pages= 427–449 |publisher= |doi= 10.1177/1745691612455204 |url= http://pps.sagepub.com/content/7/5/427.abstract |accessdate= |pmid=26168502}}</ref>
The replicability and interpretation of goal-priming findings has become controversial.<ref name="Bower2012">B. Bower. (2012). The hot and cold of priming: Psychologists are divided on whether unnoticed cues can influence behavior. ''Science News'', '''181''', [http://www.sciencenews.org/view/feature/id/340408/description/The_Hot_and_Cold_of_Priming The Hot and Cold of Priming]</ref> Recent studies have failed to replicate findings, including age priming,<ref name="Doyen2012">{{cite journal | last1 = Doyen | first1 = S. | last2 = Klein | first2 = O. | last3 = Pichon | first3 = C. L. | last4 = Cleeremans | first4 = A. | year = 2012 | title = Behavioral priming: it's all in the mind, but whose mind? | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 7 | issue = 1| page = e29081 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0029081 | pmid=22279526 | pmc=3261136| bibcode = 2012PLoSO...729081D }}</ref> with additional reports of failure to replicate this and other findings such as social-distance also reported.<ref name="Pashler2012">{{cite journal | last1 = Pashler | first1 = H. | last2 = Coburn | first2 = N. | last3 = Harris | first3 = C. R. | year = 2012 | title = Priming of social distance? Failure to replicate effects on social and food judgments | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 7 | issue = 8| page = e42510 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0042510 | pmid=22952597 | pmc=3430642| bibcode = 2012PLoSO...742510P }}</ref><ref name="PsychFileDrawer2013">PsychFileDrawer, (2013). [http://psychfiledrawer.org/topics/view.php?t=replicability-of-social-and-goal-priming-findings-3-849 Replicability of Social and goal priming findings].</ref>
Priming is often considered to play a part in the success of [[sensory branding]] of products and connected to ideas like [[crossmodal correspondencies]] and [[sensation transference]]. Known effects are e.g. consumers perceiving lemonade suddenly as sweeter when the logo of the drink is more saturated towards yellow.<ref name="Sensory Marketing Aspects">Peter Lintelle, [http://vik.sagepub.com/content/early/2016/07/07/0256090916652045.full.pdf Sensory Marketing Aspects (2014)]</ref>
==Criticism== {{expand section|date=November 2015}} Although semantic, associative, and form priming are well established,<ref name=M2014>{{cite journal | first1=D.E. | last1=Meyer | year=2014 | title= Semantic priming well established | journal=Science | volume=345 | issue=6196 | pages=523 | doi=10.1126/science.345.6196.523-b}}</ref> some longer-term priming effects were not replicated in further studies, casting doubt on their effectiveness or even existence.<ref name=BadCopy>{{cite news|last=Yong|first=Ed|title=Replication studies: Bad copy|url=http://www.nature.com/news/replication-studies-bad-copy-1.10634|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=Nature}}</ref> [[Nobel Prize|Nobel laureate]] and psychologist [[Daniel Kahneman]] has called on priming researchers to check the robustness of their findings in an open letter to the community, claiming that priming has become a "''poster child for doubts about the integrity of psychological research.''"<ref>{{cite web|last=Kahneman|first=Daniel|title=A proposal to deal with questions about priming effects|url=http://www.nature.com/polopoly_fs/7.6716.1349271308!/suppinfoFile/Kahneman%20Letter.pdf|publisher=Nature|accessdate=October 12, 2012}}</ref> Other critics have asserted that priming studies suffer from major [[publication bias]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Bower|first=Bruce|title=The Hot and Cold of Priming|url=http://www.sciencenews.org/view/feature/id/340408/title/The_Hot_and_Cold_of_Priming|accessdate=October 12, 2012|newspaper=Science News}}</ref> [[experimenter effect]]<ref name=Doyen2012 /> and that criticism of the field is not dealt with constructively.<ref>{{cite web|last=Yong|first=Ed|title=A failed replication draws a scathing personal attack from a psychology professor|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/notrocketscience/2012/03/10/failed-replication-bargh-psychology-study-doyen/|publisher=Discover Magazine|accessdate=October 12, 2012}}</ref>
